Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamics of caldera-scale rhyolitic magma systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to build a new understanding of the dynamic processes that create large rhyolitic magma systems and drive them into states of unrest and potential eruption. The natural laboratory at the Laguna del Maule volcanic field (LdM) in the Southern Andes of Chile presents a remarkable opportunity to investigate system dynamics while magma migration, reservoir growth, and crustal deformation are currently underway. This project will: (1) Ascertain the cause of the ongoing episode of unrest, including: (a) gauging the dimensions, depth, and melt fraction of the magma body or bodies currently beneath LdM; (b) estimating how these parameters evolve with time, and (c) assessing whether both current deformation, and longer term, ~20,000 year, uplift, reflects replenishment of the system with basalt; (2) Integrate petrologic and geochronologic data to track and model crystallization, cooling, magma mixing and heating events over the past ~100,000 years, and to determine whether the eruptive flare-up of rhyolitic lavas during the last 25,000 years shares a common, shallow source of melt or has more diffuse origins deeper in the crust; and (3) Create coupled numerical models that will link the observations to the physics and chemistry of the multi-phase magma-crust system over a variety of timescales.

Since Earth will eventually experience another caldera-forming rhyolitic eruption, there is a need to gather comprehensive information and create models that realistically account for the dynamics that lead to these destructive events. Meeting this challenge will require understanding: (1) the slow geologic processes, magmatic conditions, and structural changes that propel assembly and growth of these systems, and (2) the dynamics of a complex multiphase system on both long (years to millennia), and short (days to months) human time scales. A firm grasp on the coupling among these processes is currently lacking because they operate on scales ranging over many orders of magnitude temporally and spatially. This project affords a unique opportunity to investigate the dynamics of such a system while magma migration, reservoir growth, and astonishing crustal deformation are currently underway. Exploring this frontier through both observations and novel modeling approaches will yield unprecedented insight into system dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large-scale, caldera forming volcanic systems are common features of many subduction zones and pose a major recurring threat to the Earth?s surface. The compositionally evolved magmas involved are the eruptive equivalent of granites and indicative of processes that are posited as being responsible for the growth of continental crust. These eruptions are also some of the most destructive natural phenomena. In the last several hundred years about a dozen moderate (> 5 km3), yet highly destructive, eruptions occurred at subduction zone volcanoes. In contrast, explosive caldera-scale systems can rapidly deposit 100s of cubic kilometers of volcanic ash, posing a hazard to people and infrastructure at the scale of an entire content. While we have learned a great deal about the result of these eruptions from their depositional record, it has been a challenge to combine long timescale information available from deposits and geochemistry, with geophysical approaches that capture a contemporary snap shot of these systems.

 

The Laguna del Maule (LdM) volcanic field in the southern Andes presents a remarkable opportunity to investigate magmatic system dynamics while magma migration, reservoir growth, and crustal deformation are currently underway. Over the past decade ground deformation at LdM exceeded 280 mm/yr and continues to the present day, and >350 km3 of magmas have erupted in this volcanic field since the Pleistocene, included at least 36 eruptive events since the end of the last glaciation. Many of these magmas are rhyolites and are exceptionally preserved, recording the thermal and compositional evolution of magma bodies in the region. This project combined petrology, geochemistry, a suite of geophysical approaches including gravity, deformation, magnetotellurics and seismology, and novel numerical methods to examine the evolution of the magmatic system and link different observations in a self-consistent physical model.

This project involved several US institutions and had a broader impact of strengthening international research ties with partners in Chile and Argentina. This close arrangement, and interaction with local press and communities, promoted a greater appreciation for the hazards of these volcanic systems. In the case of Laguna del Maule, there is also vital infrastructure in the region, including a hydroelectric facility associated with the lake itself. The on-going deformation already presents an engineering challenge and future eruptions pose a range of hazards. Another broader impact of this work from the University of Oregon was the training of two graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher.

The University of Oregon component focused on numerical models of the magmatic system as a way to integrate geophysical and geochemical measurements. This involved three primary and integrated modeling efforts including: 1. Generating a 3D multiphase model that included thermodynamics and predicted the thermal and compositional consequences of successive intrusions in the crust. This model simultaneously calculates heat transfer, melt dynamics, and phase equilibria.  2. Forward geophysical models to predict the geophysical signals expected from the melt fraction distribution in the crust. 3. Prediction of crystal (zircon) populations based on the chemical and thermal evolution of the system to better interpret proxies used for timescales of magmatic processes. We find that given numerous realizations of intrusion scenarios, an upper crustal reservoir of silicic melt develops, albeit with low melt fraction with transient high melt fraction bodies of 10s of cubic kilometers. These upper crustal magma bodies exist in a narrow range of flux from the mantle, and upper crustal reservoirs of melt consistent with LDM observations are accompanied by conditions conducive to the formation of complementary lower crustal reservoirs.

More generally, the rates and duration of magmatic activity in the crust control the compositions, recurrence intervals, volumes, and style of these eruptions, and determine the volcanic? to plutonic ratios during crustal differentiation. We show that the presence of large lower crustal magma bodies play a key role in priming the upper crust for magma storage by adding sensible heat and reducing the amount of thermal energy needed once upper crustal magma intrusions initiate. The intrusion rates needed for magma accumulation in the upper crust when a lower crustal reservoir is fully developed (thermally mature system) are at least an order of magnitude lower than previous estimates from thermal modeling. This is on par with geologically constrained timescales and intrusion rates at numerous volcanic and plutonic localities. Hence, magma intrusion rates should be combined with the age of the volcanic system to assess its capability to form the largest silicic eruptions on Earth.
